title: Part A(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not accurately explain that the substitution could change the shape of the protein channel so that pyrethroids can no longer affect it/can no longer bind to it/can no longer interfere with its function.

The response explains that the substitution could change the shape of the protein channel so that pyrethroids can no longer affect it/can no longer bind to it/can no longer interfere with its function.

title: Part B(iii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not accurately justify exposing mosquitoes to untreated filter paper by indicating that it shows that any observed mortality is from the insecticides rather than from the filter paper itself or any other experimental conditions.

The response justifies exposing mosquitoes to untreated filter paper by indicating that it shows that any observed mortality is from the insecticides rather than from the filter paper itself or any other experimental conditions.

title: Part C(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not accurately describe that mosquitoes from region A are much more likely to have survived to reproduce, so the region A mosquitoes will have greater evolutionary fitness.
The response describes that mosquitoes from region A are much more likely to have survived to reproduce, so the region A mosquitoes will have greater evolutionary fitness.

title: Part C(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not accurately describe the following changes in susceptibility of mosquitoes from region B to each of the drugs.

· For permethrin, there was little significant change in susceptibility until the June 2010 test, when the mosquitoes were significantly less susceptible than they had been for the previous three tests.

· For deltamethrin, there was a significant decrease in susceptibility from June 2009 to October 2009 and then a further significant decrease from October 2009 to June 2010.

The response describes the following changes in susceptibility of mosquitoes from region B to each of the drugs.

· For permethrin, there was little significant change in susceptibility until the June 2010 test, when the mosquitoes were significantly less susceptible than they had been for the previous three tests. For deltamethrin, there was a significant decrease in susceptibility from June 2009 to October 2009 and then a further significant decrease from October 2009 to June 2010.

title: Part D(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not accurately make any of the the following predictions about the mosquitoes’susceptibility to the insecticides.

· The mosquitoes will all die.

· The mosquito population will be 100% susceptible.

The response makes one of the the following predictions about the mosquitoes’ susceptibility to the insecticides.

· The mosquitoes will all die.

· The mosquito population will be 100% susceptible.

title: Part D(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both of the following pieces of evidence to support the scientists’ claim.

· The frequency of the phenylalanine allele increased from very low to much higher (from 0.17 to 0.5) for population B mosquitoes that come from an area with low insecticide use.

· The insecticides are not selecting for those mosquitoes with the phenylalanine allele, but rather that it is more likely that pyrethroid-resistant mosquitoes are migrating to the area and increasing the frequency of the phenylalanine allele in the population.

The response provides both of the following pieces of evidence to support the scientists’ claim.

· The frequency of the phenylalanine allele increased from very low to much higher (from 0.17 to 0.5) for population B mosquitoes that come from an area with low insecticide use.

· The insecticides are not selecting for those mosquitoes with the phenylalanine allele, but rather that it is more likely that pyrethroid-resistant mosquitoes are migrating to the area and increasing the frequency of the phenylalanine allele in the population.
